posts.author: RunningWithWolves
posts.content:
Hi epic builders. I was looking for a half-orc build for my Aielund saga playthrough. I really liked Panthro, because its simple but still has things going for it, like songs and umd. Not quite as annoying as pre-buffing every fight, but not as brain dead as to click and afk. I assume i need to tweak it to avoid exp penalty and change all dev. crit required feats to something different. Epic levels are no problem, since i can just get more great strength, its pre-epic im concerned about. So far i either have to take useless feats, or end up with 3 apr at 20. I thought about swapping fighter for barbarian, but i want that sweet ews. And im not sure about the optimal leveling route for 4 attacks with no xp penalty. 
Im open for other build suggestions of course, if you think that im better off with something else.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi there Running With Wolves, and welcome!

Panthro seems reasonably adaptable, and if I cock this up Valerfor will be the first to stamp all over me, I'm sure.

I don't know if you've played Aielund before, but you're unlikely to go beyond level 37, which actually helps in modifying this build, I think. Also, there aren't many groovy heavy flails in the campaign, so you might want to think about Greatsword instead.

Equally, I wouldn't be over-concerned about the xp penalty - you've got 2 3/4 BAB classes, so scaling will apply, but if you are, here are my suggestions.

Go F1, B1, F2+3, B2, F4, B3, RDD1-4, B4, RDD5-8, B5+6, F5+6 pre-epic. You can lose Power Attack, Cleave and Great Cleave. I might be tempted to replace them with Luck of Heroes, Iron Will and Toughness (you will need a decent Will save during the end-game). Now, you'd gain an extra Fighter bonus feat pre-epic and you can take your pick. Or you can keep Power Attack and Cleave and drop one of the aforementioned three.

In epic levels, you could go F7, RDD9+10, B7, F8+9, B8, F10, B9, F11, B10, F12, B11, F13+14, B12-16. You do get 1 level of 20% xp penalty at level 35, but by then you're fine anyway. The feats in epic could go: level 21, GSI; level 24, GSII; 25, EWF; 27, GSIII; 28, EWS; 30, GSIV; 32, AS; 33, GSV; 35, EP; 36, GSVI.

Hopefully that should do it.

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I'm with you all the way as far as xp penalties go, and yes could prevent them entirely with my suggestions if you went for Bard 12 at level 35 and Fighter 14 at 36 - I was just trying to get Epic Prowess in a bit earlier. The scaling I mentioned is that, while the xp penalty remains constant, you get more xp for a kill if you're not on a full BAB schedule (thus - and this is a made-up example - while you might only get 80% of the xp for a particular kill, it might well be of a 20% xp hike in the value of that kill) so it kind of balances out in the long run.

As for the pre-epic feats, a lot will depend on your own play-style. I know I only take Great Cleave if I'm going for Dev Crit (unless I've got feats to burn), and Power Attack is a bit pointless in itself for a Strength build, but you need it for Cleave (unless you're a monk), and Cleave is good. The only problems with LoH, IW and Toughness are when you have to take them. LoH can only be had at level 1, and neither IW nor Toughness can be taken as bonus feats. The Disarm twins are more useful with a 2-handed weapon, but they function in much the same way as KD/IKD do - your AB drops. But you couldn't take them anyway without an Int of 13+ (the same is true of IKD, btw), so let's not worry too much.

As for which weapon to go for, I'm basing this entirely on what's readily available in Aielund, as per your request, and there ain't many quality scythes lying around either. For a 2-hander it's either Greatsword or Greataxe. Valerfor would probably cook me in boiling oil for this (and I wouldn't blame him), but if I was going exotic with Panthro, then it's either bastard sword or katana, either with a shield.

But one of the wonderful things about Aielund (I so want to say "is that Aielund's a wonderful thing," -sorry, having a Tigger moment) is that if you're operating from a quality build in the first place you should make it through if you learn how to adapt to its strengths and weaknesses.

Cheers

As i've mentioned im willing to lower Dexterity for some Intelligence in order to get Disarm, since i will likely wear a Dex item to cap AC in fullplate anyway, or buff it with potion or scroll. I also don't need any other stat aside from STR in this build. 
I just tested Disarm on some guards and it didn't work, but then i tested it on rangers and it worked perfectly. They seem to have poor ai and don't pick their weapons up. Also if i understand correctly if you have Imp. Disarm and wield a bigger category weapon, then you don't have a penalty to attack or even get a bonus to it. If it works this well in epic levels, when enemies have nasty enchanted weapons i think it will be useful in the fights with humanoids. 
So far it looks like a better choice to me. At least its one more button to press since the build doesn't have spells. Seems more substantial than small bonus to Saves on a build that isn't focused on high saves. Unless of course im missing something and in that case i'll be thankful for any insight.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
As I said before, you will need a reasonable will save as you approach the end game. I don't want to throw spoilers out, but you may well have gained an item that boosts will nicely before then. Even so, you don't want a will save below around the mid 20s.

As far as Disarm goes, it's a -6 to your attack roll (-4 with Imp Disarm). You do get up to +4 on the attempt with a large weapon assuming it's against a smaller weapon. You're open to AoO with straight Disarm, but not with Improved. And it's normal damage. It checks against Fortitude.

Your call as to whether it's worth it.
